meta.description: Mental game scenarios for psychology training

tilt_control.name: Tilt Control
tilt_control.description: Managing emotions after bad beats and coolers

scenarios.title: The River Suckout
scenarios.context: You're in a $500 tournament, 20 players from the money. You get it all-in preflop with AA vs KK for a 150bb pot. The board runs out K-7-2-J-K. You just lost to quads.

options.text: Take a short break, do some breathing exercises, then return with a clear mind
options.feedback: Perfect. Taking a tactical break to reset emotionally is the optimal play. Your remaining stack needs your A-game.

options.text: Play the next few hands ultra-tight until you calm down
options.feedback: While better than tilting off, playing scared poker costs you EV. Your emotions are still affecting your decisions.

options.text: Try to win it back quickly by playing more hands
options.feedback: This is revenge tilt. Trying to 'win it back' leads to poor decisions and usually more losses.

options.text: Keep playing normally - bad beats happen
options.feedback: Suppressing emotions without processing them often leads to hidden tilt. Acknowledge the feeling, then move on strategically.

scenarios.title: The Cooler Cascade
scenarios.context: In the last 30 minutes, you've lost: set over set, flush over flush, and just now AA vs AK all-in pre where villain hit a K. Your bankroll is down 5 buy-ins.
scenarios.prompt: How do you handle this situation?

options.text: End your session immediately and review hands tomorrow with a clear head
options.feedback: Excellent discipline. Recognizing when you're not playing your best and preserving your bankroll is a winning mindset.

options.text: Move down in stakes to protect your bankroll
options.feedback: Moving down while tilted just means losing at lower stakes. Address the mental state first.

options.text: Keep playing - variance evens out eventually
options.feedback: While true about variance, playing through heavy tilt compounds the problem. You need a reset.

options.text: Move up in stakes to recover losses faster
options.feedback: This is textbook tilt behavior. Moving up when running bad accelerates bankroll destruction.

scenarios.title: The Chat Tilter
scenarios.context: A recreational player just called your river bluff with bottom pair and typed 'LMAO SO OBVIOUS' in chat. You know your play was theoretically correct.

options.text: Mute chat, take a breath, and continue playing your game
options.feedback: Perfect response. Don't let external noise affect your internal game. Your play was correct - results don't change that.

options.text: Type 'NH' and move on
options.feedback: While civil, engaging at all keeps you mentally connected to the hand. Better to fully disengage.

options.text: Explain why your play was mathematically correct
options.feedback: Trying to educate fish is -EV. They won't understand, and you're wasting mental energy.

options.text: Target this player specifically in future hands
options.feedback: Revenge targeting leads to forced plays and poor decisions. Let your good play naturally exploit their mistakes.

fear_management.name: Fear Management
fear_management.description: Overcoming fear of big pots and tournament pressure

scenarios.title: The Final Table Bubble
scenarios.context: You're on the bubble of a $10K tournament final table. 9 players left, 8 get paid. You have 15bb in the BB. The chip leader (50bb) opens to 2.5x from the CO. You look down at QQ.

options.text: This is a clear shove spot - ICM considerations don't change that QQ is far ahead of their range
options.feedback: Correct mindset. While ICM matters, QQ is too strong to fold. Trust your strategy and make the +EV play.

options.text: Fold and wait for a better spot - min-cashing is better than bubbling
options.feedback: Folding QQ here is a massive ICM mistake. Fear of bubbling is costing you significant equity in the tournament.

options.text: Just call and see a flop to avoid risk
options.feedback: Flatting QQ out of position with 15bb is terrible. You're making a scared poker play.

options.text: Shove and hope for the best - whatever happens, happens
options.feedback: The action is correct but the mindset is wrong. You should shove because it's strategically correct, not because you've given up on thinking.

scenarios.title: The Monster Pot
scenarios.context: You're playing $5/$10 cash, your biggest stakes ever. You have top set on a J-7-2 rainbow board. The pot is $800 and your opponent just raised your bet to $2,400. You have $4,000 behind.
scenarios.prompt: What mental approach should you take?

options.text: Focus on the strategic decision - evaluate their range and respond optimally
options.feedback: Exactly right. The dollar amounts are just numbers. Focus on making the correct poker decision regardless of stakes.

options.text: Just call to control the pot size and minimize risk
options.feedback: Pot controlling with top set is leaving massive value on the table. You're letting fear dictate your strategy.

options.text: Fold - they probably have a bigger set
options.feedback: Folding top set here is a catastrophic mistake. You're monster hunting based on fear, not logic.

options.text: Shove immediately - no way they have 77 or 22
options.feedback: The action might be correct, but the reasoning isn't. Dismissing their possible holdings is overconfident.

discipline.name: Session Discipline
discipline.description: Maintaining focus and making quality decisions

scenarios.title: The Long Session
scenarios.context: You've been playing a cash session for 8 hours. You're up 3 buy-ins but feeling mentally fatigued. You just made a questionable call that happened to work out. A new player just sat down with a full stack.

options.text: Lock up the win and end the session - fatigue is clearly affecting your decisions
options.feedback: Perfect read on yourself. Recognizing diminished decision quality and protecting your profit shows elite discipline.

options.text: Stay for one more orbit to evaluate the new player
options.feedback: Slippery slope. One orbit becomes one hour. If you're fatigued, the new player's presence doesn't matter.

options.text: Order some coffee and push through - you're running hot
options.feedback: Running hot is not a reason to play tired. Variance gave you those chips; fatigue will give them back.

options.text: Take a 15-minute break then continue playing
options.feedback: After 8 hours, a short break won't restore full cognitive function. You need proper rest.

scenarios.title: The Distraction
scenarios.context: You're playing an important MTT. During a crucial hand, your phone buzzes with a work emergency. You're facing a tough decision with 2 minutes on your time bank.

options.text: Ignore the phone, focus on the hand, deal with work after making your decision
options.feedback: Correct prioritization. The hand in front of you requires your full attention. Work can wait 2 minutes.

options.text: Quickly check the phone while the time bank runs
options.feedback: Split attention leads to poor decisions in both areas. You'll make a worse poker decision AND a rushed work response.

options.text: Fold and handle the work emergency immediately
options.feedback: Folding a tough spot because of external distraction is letting non-poker factors dictate your strategy.

options.text: Let the hand time out while you check the phone
options.feedback: Timing out is the worst outcome. You're neither making a poker decision nor properly handling work.

confidence.name: Confidence Building
confidence.description: Trusting your reads and making bold plays

scenarios.title: The Hero Call Spot
scenarios.context: On the river, the board is K-Q-7-4-2 rainbow. You have A-K. The pot is $500, and your opponent just bet $400. You've noticed they've been bluffing a lot, but this time they look confident.

options.text: Analyze their full range and bet sizing - physical tells are unreliable
options.feedback: Exactly. Live tells can deceive you. Focus on their range construction, bet sizing, and the overall hand narrative.

options.text: Trust your read that they look confident and fold
options.feedback: Physical tells are often wrong or intentionally misleading. Folding top pair top kicker based on 'confidence' is weak.

options.text: Call instantly to show you can't be bullied
options.feedback: Ego-based decisions are -EV. Make the call if it's correct, not to prove a point.

options.text: Raise to find out where you stand
options.feedback: Raising for information on the river with a bluff catcher is a common mistake. You're either value-owned or folding out bluffs.

scenarios.title: The Ambitious Bluff
scenarios.context: You've identified a spot where a triple barrel bluff makes sense. The math says it should work 60% of the time. Your heart is racing as you contemplate the river bet.

options.text: Execute the bluff confidently - you've done the analysis and the spot is correct
options.feedback: Perfect. Trust your preparation. If the math supports the play, physical anxiety shouldn't stop you from executing.

options.text: Size down your bluff to risk less
options.feedback: Sizing down often makes your bluff less effective while still committing chips. Either execute fully or don't bluff.

options.text: Give up - the physical stress isn't worth it
options.feedback: Letting anxiety dictate your strategy costs you money. Learn to play through the discomfort.

options.text: Overbet to really put them to the test
options.feedback: If 60% is the right frequency, stick to your planned sizing. Overbetting might lower your success rate.

scenarios.title: The Heater
scenarios.context: You've won 5 buy-ins in the last hour. Every hand seems to hit. You just flopped a set again and your opponent is betting into you.

options.text: Stay focused on making correct decisions - running good doesn't change strategy
options.feedback: Perfect discipline. Winning streaks are variance too. Keep making +EV plays regardless of recent results.

options.text: Press your luck and play more hands while you're hot
options.feedback: This is winners tilt. Playing more hands because you're 'hot' is just as irrational as playing scared when running bad.

options.text: Book the win - it can only go down from here
options.feedback: Quitting just because you're ahead is results-oriented thinking. If you're playing well and the game is good, continue.

options.text: Move up in stakes to maximize the heater
options.feedback: Moving up based on recent results rather than bankroll and skill is a recipe for giving back your winnings.
